Award.AwardTitle: ARTS: Taxonomic revision of Aphelinus species of the world using advanced bioinformatics and molecular methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will produce a worldwide review of Aphelinus species, a group of minute parasitic wasps. Many new species are known to occur, including cryptic species that differ only slightly in traditional morphological characters. Specimens will be photographed to record coloration and taxonomic characters, DNA will be extracted using non-destructive methods, and next-generation sequencing methods will be used to generate molecular characters. The data will be analyzed to characterize species and to provide an evolutionary framework for classification. Selected crosses will confirm reproductive isolation. An on-line data management system will be used to store and organize collection records, literature, digital images and morphological and molecular data. Following publication of the results, data will be delivered to online sources of global biodiversity information.

Aphelinus species are natural enemies of aphids, and a comprehensive and robust taxonomy will greatly facilitate their use in the biological control of those important pests. Rates of speciation are extremely rapid in Aphelinus, making species difficult to characterize using traditional molecular methods. Next-generation sequencing will provide orders of magnitude more information to infer evolutionarily relationships, and the project is one of the first to apply these methods to insect taxonomy. Two graduate students will be broadly trained in the theory and methods of contemporary systematic biology. Aphelinus species are superb model systems for study of speciation in parasitoids, and the complex, inter-related effects of mate recognition, host-switching, and endosymbionts. This project will provide the essential foundation for these studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project was conducted by scientists at Texas A&M University and the USDA/ARS/Beneficial Insect Introduction Laboratory, Newark DE.  The project was a comprehensive study of the genus Aphelinus, an important group of parasitic wasps, all of which attack species of aphids.  Because aphids are important agricultural, forest, and horticultural pests, species of Aphelinus have been very widely used as natural or biological control agents, as an alternative to the use of pesticides.  However, species of Aphelinus are often very difficult to distinguish based on anatomical features, and even closely related, very similar species can differ in the aphid hosts that are attacked and other important biological properties.  Therefore, it is essential that species in the genus are well understood, and that tools are available to enable their accurate identification.  This project studied all available specimens of Aphelinus from insect collections worldwide, consisting of many thousands of specimens.  The goal was to assess the limits of all 128 species of Aphelinus that have been described, determine which represent valid, biological species, and which are synonyms of other species (species that have been described more than once with different names).  This type of project is known as a taxonomic revision, and it provides a solid foundation for all subsequent biological research, as well as use of these species in agriculture.  Existing valid species were redescribed and new species were described, using comprehensive and consistent sets of anatomical features.  Because these insects are minute (about 1 mm. long), special techniques were used including slide-mounting and dissection of specimens.  Field work to obtain high quality specimens was conducted in Colorado, Texas, and Delaware and  collaborators in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Hawaii, California, Missouri, and México provided fresh material.

Advanced digital imaging techniques were used to create high resolution digital images of critical features used for identification.  Advanced molecular biological methods were used to provide a critical backbone of DNA sequence data to infer evolutionary history and to assess which entities represent valid biological species.  In this case, whole genomes were obtained from 16 species of Aphelinus and selected relatives, as well as reduced representation libraries containing both coding and non-coding DNA sequences.  We identified 3,985 different structural genes in Aphelinus that can be used for phylogenetic analysis and many other purposes.  We also obtained the karyotypes (formal descriptions of their chromosomes) of nine species of Aphelinus and used flow cytometry methods to estimate the genome size of 14 species.  These data will be available to scientists worldwide, along with almost 1900 digital images of Aphelinus and comprehensive anatomical data, using an on-line data aggregation and delivery system known as MX.  To date, five new species have been described and numerous species have been redescribed.  The results confirm the validity of several species groups of Aphelinus that have been used to organize groups of similar species, and they shed new light on the relationships and evolutionary history of the components of Aphelinus.  To date, six scientific publications and numerous presentations at scientific conferences have resulted from the project, and additional publications are in preparation.

Broader impacts of the research included training new scientists in the methods and techniques of contemporary taxonomic research, to develop the human infrastructure and scientific expertise needed to continue this type of research with parasitic wasps.  We trained two postdoctoral researchers, two graduate students, two research assistants, three technicians, and numerous undergraduate students in the theory and methods of contemporary systematics research, including phylogenomics and advanced methods for imaging and phylogenetic analysis.  The project has several other broader impacts.  Because our usage of anatomical terms is consistent with current standards set by the Hymenoptera Anatomy Ontology project, data on character traits for Aphelinus species are accessible to researchers worldwide in functional morphology, developmental biology, and many other fields.  Sequencing and annotation of Aphelinus genomes will provide significant new insights into the structure and architecture of insect genomes, specifically parasitic Hymenoptera, and it will be a tremendous resource for research on the molecular evolution and genetics of insect parasitoids.  Aphelinus is one of the primary sources of species for natural and biological control of aphid pests of agriculture.  We are directly collaborating with researchers worldwide in the biological control and management of aphid pests, and we have provided authoritative identifications of the species they are working with.  Finally, development of natural history research collections was a core activity in the project.  Considerable effort was expended on collection of new material and preparation of high quality insect specimens that will become part of the Texas A&M University Insect Collection and the National Museum of Natural History, Washington DC.  The value of specimens borrowed from many other collections worldwide was considerably enhanced by slide-mounting and application of individual accession numbers or bar-code labels, according to the protocols for each collection.
